about.summary: R comes with a suite of utilities for linear algebra with "numeric" (double precision) vectors/matrices. However, sometimes single precision (or less!) is more than enough for a particular task.  This package extends R's linear algebra facilities to include 32-bit float (single precision) data. Float vectors/matrices have half the precision of their "numeric"-type counterparts but are generally faster to numerically operate on, for a performance vs accuracy trade-off.  The internal representation is an S4 class, which allows us to keep the syntax identical to that of base R's. Interaction between floats and base types for binary operators is generally possible; in these cases, type promotion always defaults to the higher precision.  The package ships with copies of the single precision 'BLAS' and 'LAPACK', which are automatically built in the event they are not available on the system.

name: r-float
raw_recipe:
{% set version = '0.2-3' %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}
{% set native = 'm2w64-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-float
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/float_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/float/float_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: 32430b5c0665bf4486853d714bf2f053c5aaa544dc99b48a80540d528abcc0e9

build:
  merge_build_host: True  # [win]
  number: 0
  skip: True  # [r_base == "3.5.1"]
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}              # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}        # [win]
    - {{ compiler('fortran') }}        # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_fortran') }}  # [win]
    - {{posix}}filesystem        # [win]
    - {{posix}}sed               # [win]
    - {{posix}}grep              # [win]
    - {{posix}}autoconf
    - {{posix}}automake          # [not win]
    - {{posix}}automake-wrapper  # [win]
    - {{posix}}pkg-config
    - {{posix}}make
    - {{posix}}coreutils         # [win]
    - {{posix}}zip               # [win]
  host:
    - libopenblas
    - _openmp_mutex              # [linux]
    - llvm-openmp                # [osx]
    - r-base
  run:
    - libopenblas
    - _openmp_mutex              # [linux]
    - llvm-openmp                # [osx]
    - r-base
    - {{native}}gcc-libs         # [win]

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('float')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('float')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://github.com/wrathematics/float
  license: BSD_2_clause
  summary: R comes with a suite of utilities for linear algebra with "numeric" (double precision)
    vectors/matrices. However, sometimes single precision (or less!) is more than enough
    for a particular task.  This package extends R's linear algebra facilities to include
    32-bit float (single precision) data. Float vectors/matrices have half the precision
    of their "numeric"-type counterparts but are generally faster to numerically operate
    on, for a performance vs accuracy trade-off.  The internal representation is an
    S4 class, which allows us to keep the syntax identical to that of base R's. Interaction
    between floats and base types for binary operators is generally possible; in these
    cases, type promotion always defaults to the higher precision.  The package ships
    with copies of the single precision 'BLAS' and 'LAPACK', which are automatically
    built in the event they are not available on the system.
  license_family: BSD
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/BSD_2_clause'
    - LICENSE

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r

# Package: float
# Type: Package
# Title: 32-Bit Floats
# Version: 0.2-3
# Description: R comes with a suite of utilities for linear algebra with "numeric" (double precision) vectors/matrices. However, sometimes single precision (or less!) is more than enough for a particular task.  This package extends R's linear algebra facilities to include 32-bit float (single precision) data. Float vectors/matrices have half the precision of their "numeric"-type counterparts but are generally faster to numerically operate on, for a performance vs accuracy trade-off.  The internal representation is an S4 class, which allows us to keep the syntax identical to that of base R's. Interaction between floats and base types for binary operators is generally possible; in these cases, type promotion always defaults to the higher precision.  The package ships with copies of the single precision 'BLAS' and 'LAPACK', which are automatically built in the event they are not available on the system.

# LazyData: true
# ByteCompile: yes
# URL: https://github.com/wrathematics/float

# Authors@R: c( person("Drew", "Schmidt", role=c("aut", "cre", "cph"), email="wrathematics@gmail.com"), person("Wei-Chen", "Chen", role="aut"), person("Dmitriy", "Selivanov", role="ctb", comment="improvements in external package linking"), person("ORNL", role="cph") )

about.summary: R comes with a suite of utilities for linear algebra with "numeric" (double precision) vectors/matrices. However, sometimes single precision (or less!) is more than enough for a particular task.  This package extends R's linear algebra facilities to include 32-bit float (single precision) data. Float vectors/matrices have half the precision of their "numeric"-type counterparts but are generally faster to numerically operate on, for a performance vs accuracy trade-off.  The internal representation is an S4 class, which allows us to keep the syntax identical to that of base R's. Interaction between floats and base types for binary operators is generally possible; in these cases, type promotion always defaults to the higher precision.  The package ships with copies of the single precision 'BLAS' and 'LAPACK', which are automatically built in the event they are not available on the system.
